newsitem.title: USA: Versace death unwanted blow to Miami's glitzy image.
newsitem.headline: Versace death unwanted blow to Miami's glitzy image.

text.p: The murder on Tuesday of designer Gianni Versace in the heart of super trendy Miami Beach was a blow to a city that promotes itself as a fashion and tourist paradise while grappling with an image of a dangerous area thick with crime.

Tourist offices were flooded with telephone calls almost as soon as the news broke that the world-renowned designer had been gunned down on the steps of his mansion in South Beach, a glitzy area of upscale restaurants, art deco hotels and white sand beaches.
"We're a little overwhelmed with calls right now," said a spokeswoman at the Greater Miami Convention & Visitors Bureau.
The local fashion industry also reeled, as models, editors and businesses that rely on them reacted to the loss of a man credited with putting South Beach on the style map.

"What does Versace do for clothing? What does Versace do for boutiques? He gives a name, he gives credibility. He was the stamp of approval," said Jack Donahue, associate publisher of Fashion Spectrum, a regional magazine on the industry.

"Gianni Versace was a worldwide personality, so for the people who work here on Ocean Drive, it's really awful," said Eddie Bianchi, owner of a rollerblade shop near the Versace mansion. He said he heard the fatal shots.
The designer was shot twice in the head as he finished his daily walk to buy newspapers at the News Cafe, a beachfront spot known as a haven for the Miami Beach glamour elite.

Nine European tourists were murdered in Florida during a 12-month period in 1992-93, some of the most publicised of those attacks in Miami. Publicity about the killings, and a citywide murder rate that has remained one of the highest in the United States, scared many potential visitors away from southern Florida.

The German government even drew up formal guidelines for visitors to the area, including a warning not to stop for strangers and to avoid central Miami and Miami Beach after dark. "Miami has such a bad reputation in Germany. This is very, very bad," said Britt Steinhardt, a German flight attendant who lives part-time in Miami Beach.

Miami and Miami Beach are technically separate cities, a point that Miami Beach officials have been anxious to make as Miami sweated out a series of corruption scandals. But as far as tourists, businessmen and most residents are concerned, the two cities are perceived as one.

The decline in visitors after the 1992-93 murders was devastating to tourism, an industry considered crucial to the region's economy. Tourists spent $10.9 billion in greater Miami last year, indicating tourism has rebounded.
Yet industry professionals said the Miami area is still vulnerable to any bad news.

"After some incident, whatever it happens to be ... it's almost like an airline accident, where you have a period of heightened awareness for a little while," said Chris Privett, senior manager of communications at the American Society of Travel Agents.

The region was so concerned with its image that it kept a crowd of some 100 journalists waiting for 90 minutes in 90-degree heat for Dade County's mayor to show up on Tuesday and assure a news conference the Miami Beach police called on Versace's death that the city was still safe.

"The information that we now have suggests that this terrible crime was an extraordinary occurrence and not just a random robbery," Dade County Mayor Alex Penelas said. "Let me assure you that Miami Beach and Dade County are safe despite this terrible incident."
